Review: The place is amazing to enjoy the nature. Not that much tourists are here, so you can enjoy the peacefulness. When you go there don't forget to try the tea with the pretty garden view! (Tea picture is attached.)

Author: Coffeesaxophonne

Author: Trans-word plus TGM
Review:
Sanzen-in Temple is located in a mountainous town of Ohara in the northern part of Sakyo-ku. The temple belongs to Tendai sect of Buddhism established in the late 8th century by saint Saicho. Sain Saicho is most known as a founder of Enryakuji Temple. The main object of worship is Yakushi Nyorai statue. The origin of the temple can trace its roots to Enyubo on Mt. Hiei which is located in the south-west of Ohara during the period of Sain Saicho. It was later relocated to Ohara in 1871. This is why the temple has another name of remains of a gate to the late Sanzen-in Temple. Out of those three major Monzeki ( remains of a gate ) Temples of Tendai sect, Sanzen-in has the oldest one. There is a famous Amida Sanson Statues ( three bodies of Amida Nyorai statues ) placed in its main hall right in the center of a garden covered in deep green moss. In its precincts there are two streams running. One is called Ryosen and another one is called Ritsusen. Those names can be reffered to the rhythm of a Buddhist sutra.

The temple is built in an extensive area at the foot of a mountain and its surrounding area has many other Buddhist temples connected with a narrow paths. You could spend half a day just strolling around this area full of attractions. Along the way to the temple is a path filled with many souvenir shops. You might notice some shops selling Shibazuke ( pickled egg plants seasoned with Shiso leaves ). Shiso leaves are the local special product in Ohara. Sanzen-in is mostly visited among tourists wishing to see autumn leaves in November, but you should not miss the seasonal beauty of its Hydrangeas bloom in June. The temple is never crowded except for the autmn season. You can fully enjoy the tranquility of its atmosphere. We highly recommend that when you come to Ohara, spend the whole day exploring around the town.

( Trans-word+ : TGM Kyoto Guide )

Review: Comparatively smaller than Ginkakuji, the reason to visit is perhaps to marvel at the surrounding area leading up to the temple.  Lots of souvenir and food shops have sprung up to make the remote area more tourist friendly. Not worth the hour long or more bus ride from Kyoto station.

Author: Nika A
Review:
Extraordinary place. So zen. Spent the whole day here and visited a few of the surrounding temples too. By far one of my favourite spots.
You can enjoy the tea ceremony here (we did a couple in each spot) and just breathe in the fresh air and appreciate the view.
We also joined in on a meditation session, which was very interesting. Absolutely love everything about this place!
Best to go early in the AM.

Author: Rani S Ekawati
Review: You won't regret visit Sanzen-in in autumn. It is the most beautiful of all temples I visited in Kyoto. From Kyoto take bus number 17 to Ohara (remind you that there is city bus also number 17 that will take you to the last bus stop near Nanzen-ji, so don't mix them up). From Ohara bus stop you just have to follow people. Most of them will go to Sanzen-in anyway. The bus ride to Ohara was amazing with beautiful scenery along the way. The 700 yen of entrance fee will be worth it, you literally be able to enter all buildings, including treasure hall) and garden. This place is massive. I spent like 2 hours in this place to cover all the area. Be ready for dreamy scenery all over the place in autumn. It may take around 1 hr from Tokyo station, but go here anyway.  You won't regret it. Make sure to walk on all the narrow path here, especially near the bridge. If you are here to see jizo statues, they are in the most garden and at the far end near the bridge.

Author: Poppy Le Chat
Review: Meow. Feeling uplifted visiting this beautiful place. I visited in early February, so colours were not as vivid as peak seasons. Still, the design of the temple, viewing gardens, strolling gardens and temple grounds were lovely for contemplation. They serve matcha and a sweet for 500yen which you can enjoy while facing the garden. While this is an hour by bus from downtown Kyoto, it is a easy ride and good (half) day trip out of the city hustle bustle, especially if you‚Äôve seen many of central Kyoto‚Äôs gardens already. The short walk up to the temple is dotted with restaurants, pickle merchants, and souvenir shops. We also visited other temples in the area. 4 paws, meow! üêæüêæüêæüêæ

Author: Muhammad Pandu
Review:
Out of the 8 temples I've been to in Kyoto, this is my favorite. The garden is lush, tranquil, the most forest-like, and there's something magical about the moss covering the temple grounds.

This is the most serene temple. You can walk through the corridors and enjoy the gardens either from inside the temple or the terrace. Some people spend some time just to sit and enjoy the serenity.

Sure the bus ride (Ohara #17 bus) took 40mins and there's an additional 10-minutes hike needed. But when you're inside it will all pay off.

Some good restaurants with garden views on the pathway to the temple.

Author: Ong Eng Hong
Review: Having a good garden that able to calm your mind and to saw alot of ajisai flower

Author: Marc Lefkowitz
Review: My new favorite temple in Kyoto! Peaceful and quiet. With a beautiful moss garden, huge hydrangea garden, and walking path along a stream. It's a bit of a hike to get out to but it's well worth it. There are a few other temples within walking distance so you can spend a few hours yo8 there.

Author: Luna Z
Review: Gorgeous temple in the outskirts of Kyoto. It‚Äôs not too hot compared to Kyoto downtown in summer. The statues of the little monks are adorable. So nice to go there alone and meditate for a while. There are some shops that sell snacks and souvenirs on the small hike to the temple. The bus near the temple doesn‚Äôt come very often so please watch the time if you‚Äôre trying to get back to Kyoto at the end of the day.

They are helpers to the common human being. Also, don‚Äôt miss Otonashi (soundless) Waterfall with bamboo and cedar on opposite sides.

Author: Latifa DNI
Review:
It was a great time, me and my husband went there to see the hydrangea/ajisai garden‚Ä¶and it was worth it!  So many beautiful blue hydrangeas.

We also love to see the zen garden from the main hall and the moss garden. The temple is really peaceful and energize me.

One of Kyoto go-to list, just take the Bus number 17 bound to Ohara, and ride it till the last station (Ohara). From there you just need to walk another 12 minutes. The scenery of the surrounding area is worth to see, really captivating and relaxing!

If you bought the one day pass, you must pay additional fare before you get off, so please be prepared.

The entrance fee of the temple is 700¬• but it‚Äôs worth it! You‚Äôll see different sensation and calmness from the temple itself and the surrounding area.

Don‚Äôt forget to looking for Warabe Jizo, small statues that lies on the moss :)

Author: Peter B.
Review: Buddist temple & tourist place

Author: Theo W
Review: This was my Disney Land. We visited while it was raining, which unexpectedly brought out a different aspect of the beauty and tranquility of this place. I dare say, visiting in the rain is preferred given the smaller crowds, peace and quiet, and vivid hues of green only rain can bring out. We'll be back.

Author: Matthew H
Review:
Lovely temple in a peaceful part of town.

Especially lovely in the winter when the snow arrives.

Author: Phuong Nguyen
Review:
It is a group of tourist attraction. You can spend all day in this area. Some restaurants, cafes and souvenir shops are nearby. Souvenir shops offer local picklings as well.

The main temple has an amazing moss covered garden. July seems to be the best time to visit the ajisai garden in the temple.

Author: Rory Rosszell
Review: This temple is well worth a visit. We rented a car, but public transportation from Kyoto is also available. We enjoyed every minute, from the long and meandering path that takes you to the gate, to the gardens, to drinking delicious matcha while you soak up the beauty of the garden, to the tasty lunch we had in a restaurant with very simple but tasteful decor just outside the gate. Highly recommended.

Author: Timothy HALL
Review: Very beautiful temple with long history. Very beautiful and popular during the fall foliage season. The moss on the ground here is a very famous/popular reason for people visiting. Be careful to check the rules first before coming. I believe that there is a no-tripod rule for photographers. Also the cost of admission to temple grounds may be expensive. Check ahead before visiting.

Author: Tetsu Yamada
Review: An hour by bus from the center of Kyoto city . It is a place where you can relax in the beautiful garden. And there is a beautiful moss.

Author: Zane Ritchie
Review: Always more to discover in this huge complex. Allow a good half a day! Amazing at any time of year.

Author: YOM BOH
Review: It was very good.

Author: Michael W. Miller
Review: A tranquil, moss-covered paradise.  The adorable jizo are enough of a draw, but the lushly landscaped (and meticulously maintained!) gardens are, perhaps, the most peaceful place on Earth.

Author: Ross Parish
Review: I don't go to temples for the religious significance, only for the unique moments of tranquility I feel as I lay eyes on a piece of garden or an architectural feature. I think I caught this temple at s weird time, with overcast/drizzly weather and not yet in real fall leaf time. That said, many temples do offer a wonderful calming experience, especially in the rain and even without the leaves. This temple felt a little overhyped and did not really do it for me. Aspects of it were beautiful, and the landscaped garden area was huge, but it was a bear to get to and I didn't like having to figure out which of the parking lots wasn't a ripoff. (Answer: park as close as possible to the entrance and you will get the best deal.)

Author: michael see
Review: We traveled more than an hour by bus from Kyoto station to the foot of the mountain and visited the temple. The claim up was easy and the surrounding was tranquil. However due to the height of the mountain the cherry blossoms were not in full bloom yet. Didn‚Äôt get into the temple itself but enjoy the surroundings very much and the claim up to the waterfall was refreshing and a good exercise. If there are not many other place to visit, this can be a good option. The restaurant near to it served healthy food with a nice vibe. The onsen was not open on the day else will be even better.

Author: ling Chou
Review: Sanzen-in Temple is located in Ohara in the northern part of Kyoto. The scenery is very beautiful. There are two beautiful gardens in Sanzen-in Temple, one of which is "Jubi-en" in front of the guest hall, and the other garden is "Yukei-en" „ÄÇIn the vast temple of Sanzen-in Temple, there are towering old trees and moss everywhere, and smiling Jizo Buddha can be seen everywhere in the moss-covered garden. Visitors can sit by the window of the guest hall and enjoy the beautiful scenery of the garden while tasting matcha and refreshments„ÄÇ
